It's worth mentioning here that both sides have castled, so that makes things slightly easier for black because his King has been moved to safety while white king is exposed in the center of the board somewhat. Still, there isn't any significant material difference between the two sides. White has some developmental lead over black but nothing major to take advantage of yet unless Black blunders or walks into a trap. As an analogy, if we were to compare this position to poker hand rankings then it would be something like having four queens against three aces with all other cards being equivalent. However, it's important to remember than in Chess games and in particular endgames - especially those without pawns, positions often don't directly translate to card hands and require much more complex analysis due to having far fewer pieces overall. Thus, although this position appears even initially; there could very well be hidden factors or tricks depending upon how each side chooses to continue. For example, if White continues with 35.Ke4 and forces black to capture after recapturing from g6, he will expose himself further on dark squares where light squared bishop is waiting. So while Black might not be able to capitalize immediately, such tactics could become relevant later down the road when considering endgame strategies once most other pieces have been traded off-board.

There are two Pawns on the board. The White King's pawn is at d4 while the Black King's pawn is at e7 (as there has been an even number of turns). Since the other pawn on the board was moved from f5 with Black's last move, we know that it is still on the board. Therefore, there are 2+0=2 pieces on this board. Note that there would have been three pieces if Black had not played his turn, which could be confusing since in many games there will typically be more than four pieces present for each player throughout most of the game. In such cases, you may want to add additional context to your response so that I can better understand what pieces were removed or added via various moves and rule-sets. For example, "There are two Kings, two Rooks, two Bishops, two Knights, and eight Pawns" for a total of ten pieces. This sentence would also be appropriate if there had only ever been two players who both chose to use all their starting units during setup. However, when using alternate setups involving fewer players or removing pieces before beginning the game, please simply count up how many pieces remain as usual.

data.sampled: 9. d4 cd4? (The computer would instead respond with 9. Be2.) d4 is incorrect because if Black captures the pawn on d4 with his pawn, White can then capture this new black pawn on d4 with his knight, resulting in an immediate win for white since there is nothing to stop him from doing so. The proper move would be 9...Be6 attacking the bishop while simultaneously preparing to castle kingside. After 10. dxe5 Ng4! black has equalized the game due to the threat of ...Nxf2 winning a rook.
